title: Lamar Odom reflects on his near-fatal 2015 overdose as he is eliminated from Dancing With The Stars
text:
Lamar Odom reflected on his near-fatal 2015 overdose as he was eliminated from Dancing With The Stars on Monday.

The ex husband of Khloe Kardashian, 39, and his pro partner Peta Murgatroyd were voted off the ballroom show after falling in the bottom two with Queer Eye star Karamo Brown.

And the former basketball player took the elimination in his stride as he remarked he was 'lucky to be walking and talking' after overdosing in a Nevada brothel four years before - and slipping into a four day coma.

Brave: Lamar Odom reflected on his near-fatal 2015 overdose as he was eliminated from Dancing With The Stars on Monday

The star said: 'I'm lucky to be walking and talking, so this is just another hill I've had to climb.'

Lamar and Peta scored 20 out of 40 for their Viennese Waltz and were eliminated from the competition after a vote from the judges.

Carrie Ann Inaba and Bruno Tonioli voted for Karamo and his dance partner Jenna Johnson, cementing Lamar's exit from the competition.

Lamar faced an extensive road to recovery after he fell into a coma after a drug overdose at a Nevada brothel.

Lucky to be alive: The former basketball player took the elimination in his stride as he remarked he was 'lucky to be walking and talking' after overdosing in a Nevada brothel four years before - and slipping into a four day coma

In a 2017 interview, the star recalled he had been in the habit of heavily abusing narcotics at the time.

'At that point in my life, I was doing coke every day. Pretty much every second of free time that I had, I was doing coke. I couldn't control it. I didn't want to control it.'

The New York native ended up at Sunrise Hospital in Las Vegas after the alarming incident.

He recalled having a wake-up call while 'trapped all day' in his thoughts at the Nevada medical center.

Inspiration: The ex husband of Khloe Kardashian, 39, and his pro partner Peta Murgatroyd was voted off the ballroom show off after falling in the bottom two with Queer Eye star Karamo Brown

'I was laying there in that bed, hooked up to all these machines, people all around me crying, and there was no running from it anymore. It was like God was telling me, 'Whatever the f*** you think you're doing, you need to slow down. Or it's gonna be worse than this,'' he said.

While Lamar admitted to initially using coke to numb the pain of losing loved ones, he explained he wasn't doing drugs on a daily basis until the death of his infant son Jayden.

In 2006, the six-month-old passed away from sudden infant death syndrome.

'I think everything probably picked up at that point, with the drugs. Even subconsciously. You don't even know why you're doing it at that point. I think subconsciously, you make yourself an addict because of the trauma that you're going through,' the father confessed.

Candid: The star said: 'I'm lucky to be walking and talking, so this is just another hill I've had to climb'

Thank you: Carrie Ann Inaba and Bruno Tonioli voted for Karamo and his dance partner Jenna Johnson, cementing Lamar's exit from the competition

The two-time NBA champ expressed that he felt invincible up until the point he wound up in a coma.

'When you’re an addict, nothing can get through to you. I never thought I was going to die. I never thought I’d be in a coma. I didn’t think I had a problem. But then I woke up in a bed with tubes coming out of my mouth — and it was real,' he admitted.

'Nobody is untouchable. Nobody in this life is immune to pain,' he continued.

In the wake of his nearly fatal overdose, Lamar explained that his surviving children, Destiny, 20, and Lamar Jr., 18, are 'the only things that kept [him] going.'

Once the ailing athlete had regained his ability to talk, his daughter inspired him to go to rehab under the threat of cutting off communication.

'The doctors told me that right before I woke up from the coma, my kids had come by to see me. And that broke my heart, because I had seen my own mother on her deathbed, with tubes coming out of her mouth,' he said.

The Dallas Mavericks alum explained that he's currently clean, but is still facing constant urges.

'I’m sober now. But it’s an everyday struggle. I have an addiction. I’ll always have an addiction. It never goes away. I mean, I want to get high right now. But I know that I can’t if I want to be here for my children,' he said
description: Lamar Odom reflected on his near-fatal 2015 overdose as he was eliminated from Dancing With The Stars on Monday.
